Thus, $U \notin \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{U}$ and $M \notin \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{M}$ since $|\operatorname{ext} M \cap \operatorname{cone}(\gamma([\varepsilon, 1-\varepsilon]))|$ can be made arbitrarily large by choosing $\varepsilon>0$ small enough.

Suppose cone $\Theta \neq \mathbb{R}^{2}$ or ext $M \neq B_{1}$. By Theorem 4.1 and Lemma B.5, $M \notin \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{M}$ and $|\operatorname{ext} M|<\infty$ if and only if $M$ has a deformation $M^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Def}(M)$ such that $\mathcal{F}(M)=\mathcal{F}\left(M^{\prime}\right)$. Thus, it suffices to show that $M$ has a deformation $M^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Def}(M)$ such that $\mathcal{F}(M)=\mathcal{F}\left(M^{\prime}\right)$ if and only if $M$ has a flexible chain.

By Lemma B.5, $M^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Def}(M)$ if and only if the facet-defining hyperplanes (lines) of $M^{\prime}$ are parallel translates of the facet-defining hyperplanes of $M$ and there is a surjective map $\varphi: \operatorname{ext} M \rightarrow \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}$. By taking a convex combination $\varepsilon M^{\prime}+(1-\varepsilon) M$ for $\varepsilon>0$ sufficently small, we may assume that $\varphi: \operatorname{ext} M \rightarrow \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}$ is bijective.

For $\mathcal{F}(M)=\mathcal{F}\left(M^{\prime}\right)$ to hold, $(v, \varphi(v))$ must lie on the same face of $A$. In particular, $\varphi(a)=a$ for all $a \in V(M), \varphi(I(M))=I\left(M^{\prime}\right), \varphi\left(B_{1}(M)\right)=B_{1}\left(M^{\prime}\right)$, and $\varphi\left(B_{2}(M)\right)=B_{2}\left(M^{\prime}\right)$.

We observe that if $v \in B_{1}(M)$ and $v \neq \varphi(v)$, then the two facet-defining hyperplanes of $M$ intersecting in $v$ must both be translated in $M^{\prime}$ for otherwise $(v, \varphi(v))$ cannot lie on a common edge of $A$.

Consider a deformation $M^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Def}(M)$ such that $\mathcal{F}(M)=\mathcal{F}\left(M^{\prime}\right)$; we construct a flexible chain of $M$. Find a sequence $S=\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right)$ of vertices in ext $M \backslash \varphi(\operatorname{ext} M)$ that are adjacent in the clock-wise ordering and such that no other vertex in ext $M \backslash \varphi(\operatorname{ext} M)$ is adjacent to a vertex in $S . S \cap V(M)=\emptyset$ follows since $\varphi(a)=a$ for all $a \in V(M)$. If $n=2$, then $\overline{v_{1} v_{n}} \not \subset \operatorname{bndr} A$ for otherwise the edge $\overline{\varphi\left(v_{1}\right) \varphi\left(v_{n}\right)}$ is not in bndr $A$, contradicting $\mathcal{F}(M)=\mathcal{F}\left(M^{\prime}\right)$. If $v_{1}, v_{n} \in B_{1}(M)$, then, by the previous paragraph, $v_{1}$ and $v_{n}$ cannot be the first or last vertex in the sequence, contradicting the construction of $S$.

Conversely, suppose $M \in \mathcal{M}$ has a flexible chain $\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right)$. We carry out the construction illustrated in Figure 7. Without loss of generality, we may assume $v_{2}, \ldots, v_{n-1} \in B_{1}(M)$ for otherwise, $\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right)$ has a subsequence of adjacent vertices that is a flexible chain with the desired property. Let $\left(H_{1}, \ldots, H_{n-1}\right)$ be the hyperplanes such that $H_{i}$ defines the facet $\overline{v_{i} v_{i+1}}$ for all $i=1, \ldots, n-1$.

Suppose $v_{1} \neq *$. Let $H_{0}$ be the other hyperplane of $M$ intersecting $v_{1}$. Translate $H_{1}$ by a sufficiently small amount, and let $\varphi_{1}$ be the intersection of $H_{1}^{\prime}$ and $H_{0}$. Since $v_{1} \in \operatorname{int} A \cup B_{2}$, $\varphi_{1}$ lies on the same face of $A$ as $v_{1}$. If $v_{1}=*$, translate $H_{1}$ by a sufficiently small amount to obtain $H_{1}^{\prime}$.

Let $\varphi_{2}$ be the intersection of $H_{1}^{\prime}$ with the edge of $A$ on which $v_{2}$ lies. (This intersection is non-empty as long as all translations are sufficiently small.) Let $H_{2}^{\prime}$ be the translate of $H_{2}$ that intersects $\varphi_{2}$.

Iterate the construction in the previous paragraphs to obtain a sequence of points $\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{n}\right)$ and hyperplanes $\left(H_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, H_{n-1}^{\prime}\right)$. Since $v_{n} \in \operatorname{int} A \cup B_{2} \cup\{*\}$, the hyperplane $H_{n} \neq H_{n-1}$ intersecting $v_{n}$ need not be translated to meet $\varphi_{n}$. Define $M^{\prime}$ as the polyhedron whose edges are defined by $\left(H_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, H_{n-1}^{\prime}\right)$ and by the facet-defining hyperplanes of $M$ different from $\left(H_{1}, \ldots, H_{n-1}\right)$. By construction, $M^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Def}(M)$ and $\mathcal{F}(M)=\mathcal{F}\left(M^{\prime}\right)$.

It remains to consider the case where ext $M=B_{1}(M)$ and cone $\Theta=\mathbb{R}^{2}$. We refer the reader to Lemmas 9, 17, and 18 in Mielczarek (1998) for the formal proof that $M \notin \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{M}$ if and only if the symmetry condition (23) holds. We illustrate the idea in the right panel of Figure 7: if (23) were to hold, then the dotted chain of line segments would have the same start- and endpoints, i.e., would become a deformation of the depicted extended menu.

# Appendix D. Proofs 

This appendix gathers the proofs for the results in the main text in the order of appearance. By Theorem A.2, we may prove all results either for the set of IC and IR mechanisms $\mathcal{X}$, the set of extended menus $\mathcal{M}$, or the set of indirect utility functions $\mathcal{U}$.
D.1. Proofs for Section 4. We note the following observation.

Lemma D.1. Suppose $x=\lambda x^{\prime}+(1-\lambda) x^{\prime \prime}$ for $x, x^{\prime}, x^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{X}$ of finite menu size and $\lambda \in(0,1)$. Then, $\mathcal{I C}(x)=\mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime}\right) \cap \mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime \prime}\right)$ and $\mathcal{F}(x)=\mathcal{F}\left(x^{\prime}\right) \cap \mathcal{F}\left(x^{\prime \prime}\right)$.

Proof. Let $M, M^{\prime}, M^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{M}$ be the extended menus associated with $x, x^{\prime}$, and $x^{\prime \prime}$, respectively. $M=\lambda M^{\prime}+(1-\lambda) M^{\prime \prime}$ by Theorem A.2. For $Z \subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$, let $\operatorname{Top}(Z, \theta)=\arg \max _{a \in Z} a \cdot \theta$.

By Corollary A.3, menu $(x)=\operatorname{ext} M$. Thus, $\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{I C}(x)$, i.e., $\operatorname{Top}\left(\operatorname{menu}(x), \theta^{\prime}\right) \subseteq$ $\operatorname{Top}($ menu $(x), \theta)$, if and only if $\operatorname{Top}\left(\operatorname{ext} M, \theta^{\prime}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{Top}(\operatorname{ext} M, \theta)$.

We first show $\mathcal{I C}(x) \supseteq \mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime}\right) \cap \mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime \prime}\right)$. Suppose $\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime}\right) \cap \mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime \prime}\right)$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Top}\left(\operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}, \theta^{\prime}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{Top}\left(\operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}, \theta\right) \\
& \operatorname{Top}\left(\operatorname{ext} M^{\prime \prime}, \theta^{\prime}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{Top}\left(\operatorname{ext} M^{\prime \prime}, \theta\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus,

$$
\operatorname{Top}\left(\lambda \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}+(1-\lambda) \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime \prime}, \theta^{\prime}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{Top}\left(\lambda \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}+(1-\lambda) \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime \prime}, \theta\right)
$$

Since ext $M \subseteq \lambda$ ext $M^{\prime}+(1-\lambda)$ ext $M^{\prime \prime}$, we conclude

$$
\operatorname{Top}\left(\operatorname{ext} M, \theta^{\prime}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{Top}(\operatorname{ext} M, \theta)
$$

or, equivalently, $\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{I C}(x)$.
We next show $\mathcal{I C}(x) \subseteq \mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime}\right) \cap \mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime \prime}\right)$. By interchanging the roles of $x^{\prime}$ and $x^{\prime \prime}$, it suffices to show that $\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right) \notin \mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ implies $\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right) \notin \mathcal{I C}(x)$. Assume $\operatorname{Top}\left(\operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}, \theta^{\prime}\right) \backslash \operatorname{Top}\left(\operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}, \theta\right) \neq \emptyset$, i.e., $\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right) \notin \mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$. Then,

$$
\operatorname{Top}\left(\lambda \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}+(1-\lambda) \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime \prime}, \theta^{\prime}\right) \backslash \operatorname{Top}\left(\lambda \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}+(1-\lambda) \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime \prime}, \theta\right) \neq \emptyset
$$

Since conv ext $M=\operatorname{conv}\left(\lambda \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}+(1-\lambda) \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime \prime}\right)$ and utility is linear, we conclude

$$
\operatorname{Top}\left(\operatorname{ext} M, \theta^{\prime}\right) \backslash \operatorname{Top}(\operatorname{ext} M, \theta) \neq \emptyset
$$

or, equivalently, $\left(\theta, \theta^{\prime}\right) \notin \mathcal{I C}(x)$.
$\mathcal{F}(x)=\mathcal{F}\left(x^{\prime}\right) \cap \mathcal{F}\left(x^{\prime \prime}\right)$ is immediate. If one summand is bounded way from a hyperplane, then the the convex combination must also be bounded away from the hyperplane. Conversely, if both summands make allocations on the same hyperplane, then so does their convex combination.

The following proof uses the polyhedral characterization of $\operatorname{Def}(M)$ given by (14), (15), and (16) in Appendix B. The proof idea is described right after the statement in the main text.

Proof of Theorem 4.1. The remark following Theorem 4.1 is immediate from Lemma D.1: for $x \in \mathcal{X}$, if another $x^{\prime} \in \mathcal{X}$ satisfies $\mathcal{I C}(x) \subseteq \mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ and $\mathcal{F}(x) \subseteq \mathcal{F}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$, then $x^{\prime \prime}=\varepsilon x^{\prime}+(1-\varepsilon) x$ for $0<\varepsilon<1$ satisfies $\mathcal{I C}(x)=\mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime \prime}\right)$ and $\mathcal{F}(x)=\mathcal{F}\left(x^{\prime \prime}\right)$.

Necessity is also immediate from Lemma D.1: if $x \notin \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{X}$, then the summands in the decomposition make weakly more constraints binding.

For sufficiency, suppose $\mathcal{I C}(x)=\mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ for $x, x^{\prime} \in \mathcal{X}$ of finite menu size. Let $M, M^{\prime} \in \mathcal{M}$ be the associated extended menus. By Lemma B.3, $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ are mutual deformations. In particular, there is a bijection $\varphi: \operatorname{ext} M \rightarrow \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}$.

As an intermediate observation, we claim that $\mathcal{F}(x)=\mathcal{F}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ implies, for all $a \in \operatorname{menu}(x)$ and $H \in \mathcal{F}, a \in H$ if and only if $\varphi(a) \in H$. In words, each menu item of $x$ makes the same feasibility constraints binding as the corresponding menu item in $x^{\prime}$. We have $H \in \mathcal{F}(M)=\mathcal{F}(x)$ if and only if $\max _{a \in \operatorname{ext} M} a \cdot n_{H}=c_{H}$, where $n_{H}$ is the normal vector and $c_{H}$ the right-hand side constant of the hyperplane $H \in \mathcal{F}$. Analogously, $H \in \mathcal{F}\left(M^{\prime}\right)=\mathcal{F}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ if and only if $\max _{a \in \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}} a \cdot n_{H}=c_{H}$. The proof of the claim is completed using Corollary B.4, which gives

$$
\underset{a \in \operatorname{ext} M^{\prime}}{\arg \max } a \cdot n_{H}=\varphi\left(\underset{a \in \operatorname{ext} M}{\arg \max } a \cdot n_{H}\right)
$$

We complete the proof of Theorem 4.1 using the polyhedral characterization of $\operatorname{Def}(M)$ given by (14), (15), and (16). Let $c$ and $c^{\prime}$ denote the deformation vectors associated with $M$ and $M^{\prime}$, respectively. By the previous paragraph, $\mathcal{F}(x)=\mathcal{F}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ if and only if the variables $\left(\varphi_{a}=\varphi(a)\right)_{a \in \operatorname{ext} A}$ make the same constraints in (16) binding as the variables $(a)_{a \in \operatorname{ext} A}$. $\mathcal{I C}(x)=\mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ if and only if the variables $\left(c,(a)_{a \in \operatorname{ext} M}\right)$ and $\left(c^{\prime},\left(\varphi_{a}\right)_{a \in \operatorname{ext} M}\right)$ both satisfy the constraints in (14) and make none of the constraints in (15) binding. (See the explanation of the constraints in Appendix B.) Thus, $\mathcal{F}(x)=\mathcal{F}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ and $\mathcal{I C}(x)=\mathcal{I C}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ if and only if $\left(c,(a)_{a \in \operatorname{ext} M}\right)$ and $\left(c^{\prime},\left(\varphi_{a}\right)_{a \in \operatorname{ext} M}\right)$ make the same constraints of $\operatorname{Def}(M)$ binding. The latter is equivalent to $M, M^{\prime} \notin \operatorname{ext} \operatorname{Def}(M)$ because $\operatorname{Def}(M)$ is a polytope by Lemma B.5. Finally, $M, M^{\prime} \notin \operatorname{ext} \operatorname{Def}(M)$ if and only if $x, x^{\prime} \notin \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{X}$.
D.2. Proofs for Section 5. Recall that by Theorem A.2, the definitions of homothety and exhaustiveness translate straightforwardly to extended menus $M \in \mathcal{M}$, where $\mathcal{F}(M) \subseteq \mathcal{F}$ was defined to be the set of facet-defining hyperplanes of $A$ intersected by ext $M$. Also recall that $M=\lambda M^{\prime}+(1-\lambda) M^{\prime \prime}$ is a homothetic decomposition of $M$ if $\lambda \in(0,1)$ and $M^{\prime}, M^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{M}$ are homothetic to but distinct from $M$.

Lemma D.2. $M \in \mathcal{M}$ is exhaustive if and only if $M$ has no homothetic decomposition.
Proof. Suppose ext $M=\{a\}$ is a singleton. If $a \notin \operatorname{ext} A$, then there exists $a^{\prime} \in A$ on the same faces of $A$ as $a$. Thus, $\mathcal{F}\left(a^{\prime}+\Theta^{\circ}\right)=\mathcal{F}(M)$ and $a^{\prime}+\Theta^{\circ}$ is homothetic to $M$. Thus, $M$ is not exhaustive. Conversely, if $M$ is not exhaustive, then there exists $M^{\prime}$ homothetic to $M$, i.e., $M^{\prime}=t+\lambda\left(M+\Theta^{\circ}\right)=t+\lambda a+\Theta^{\circ}$, such that $t+\lambda a$ meets an inclusion-wise larger set of hyperplanes in $\mathcal{F}$ than $a$, which implies $a \notin \operatorname{ext} A$.

Suppose ext $M=\{a\}$ is not a singleton. As an intermediate step, we will show that the set

$$
\operatorname{HC}(M)=\left\{(\lambda, t) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \mid \operatorname{ext}(\lambda M+t) \subset A\right\}
$$

of all (parameters of) homotheties of $M$ is a polytope. $\mathrm{HC}(M)$ is bounded because $A$ is bounded. Therefore, we show that $\mathrm{HC}(M)$ is the intersection of finitely many halfspaces. For this, let

$$
\mathrm{HC}_{-}(M, H)=\left\{(\lambda, t) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \mid \operatorname{ext}(\lambda M+t) \subset H_{-}\right\}
$$

where $H_{-}=\left\{z \in \mathbb{R}^{d}: z \cdot n_{H} \leq c_{H}\right\}$ is the halfspace that contains $A$ and is bounded by the facet-defining hyperplane $H \in \mathcal{F}$ of $A$. Let $\mathrm{HC}(M, H)$ denote the associated hyperplane. Equivalently,

$$
\mathrm{HC}_{-}(M, H)=\left\{(\lambda, t) \in \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \mid \lambda \max _{a \in \operatorname{ext} M} a \cdot n_{H}+t \cdot n_{H} \leq c_{H}\right\}
$$

That is, $\mathrm{HC}_{-}(M, F)$ is a halfspace in $\mathbb{R}^{d+1}$ with normal $\left(\max _{a \in \operatorname{ext} M} a \cdot n_{H}, n_{H}\right)$. Thus,

$$
\mathrm{HC}(M)=\mathrm{HC}_{+} \cap \bigcap_{H \in \mathcal{F}} \mathrm{HC}_{-}(M, H)
$$

is a polytope, where $\mathrm{HC}_{+}=\mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}$.
We complete the proof by showing that $M$ is exhaustive if and only if $(\lambda, t)=(1,0) \in$ $\operatorname{ext} \mathrm{HC}(M)$. Note that $(1,0)$ does not lie on the boundary of $\mathrm{HC}_{+}$. Every other halfspace $\mathrm{HC}_{-}(M, H)$ of $\mathrm{HC}(M)$ corresponds to a facet-defining hyperplane $H$ of $A$. Thus, $M$ is determined by its binding feasibility constraints $\mathcal{F}(M)$ up to homothety, i.e., exhaustive, if and only if $(1,0)$ lies on an inclusion-wise maximal set of facet-defining hyperplanes of $\mathrm{HC}(M)$. The latter condition is what it means for a point to be an extreme point of a polytope.

# Proof of Theorem 5.2. Immediate from Lemma D.2. 

Proof of Theorem 5.3. By Lemma D.2, $M \in \mathcal{M}$ is not exhaustive if and only if $M$ has a homothetic decomposition, i.e., there exist $M^{\prime}, M^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{M}$ homothetic to $M$ such that $M=\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime \prime}$.

Suppose ext $M=\{a\}$ is a singleton. Then $M$ has a homothetic decomposition if and only if $a \notin \operatorname{ext} A$. Thus, for the remainder of the proof, assume that ext $M$ is not a singleton.
$M$ has a homothetic decomposition if and only if one of the following holds:
(1) There exists a point $z \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ and $\varepsilon>0$ such that $z+(1+\varepsilon)(\operatorname{ext} M-z)$ and $z+(1-\varepsilon)(\operatorname{ext} M-z)$ are both subsets of $A$ (dilation with center $z$ ).
(2) There exists a direction $t \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash\{0\}$ such that ext $M+t$ and ext $M-t$ are both subsets of $A$ (translation).
The reason is that any homothety is itself either a dilation or translation. ${ }^{44}$
If (1) is true and $a \in H \cap \operatorname{ext} M$ for some $H \in \mathcal{F}(M)$, then $z \in H$, for otherwise $z+(1+\varepsilon)(a-z)$ or $z+(1-\varepsilon)(a-z)$ is not in $A$. Thus, if (1) is true, $\bigcap_{H \in \mathcal{F}(M)} H \neq \emptyset$. Conversely, if $\bigcap_{H \in \mathcal{F}(M)} H \neq \emptyset$, choose any $z \in \bigcap_{H \in \mathcal{F}(M)} H$. For $\varepsilon>0$ sufficiently small, $z+(1+\varepsilon)(\operatorname{ext} M-z)$ and $z+(1-\varepsilon)(\operatorname{ext} M-z)$ are both subsets of $A$. This is because ext $M$ is uniformly bounded away from facet-defining hyperplanes $H \notin \mathcal{F}(M)$ and because $a \in H \in \mathcal{F}(M)$ implies $(z+(1 \pm \varepsilon)(a-z)) \in H$ by the definition of $z$, i.e., all facet-defining inequalities of $A$ remain satisfied.

If (2) is true, then $t$ is orthogonal to all the normals of the hyperplanes in $\mathcal{F}(M)$ for otherwise there is a point $a \in \operatorname{ext} M \cap H$, for some $H \in \mathcal{F}(M)$, such that $a+t \notin H$ or

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{44}$ Specifically, suppose $M=\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime \prime}$ and $M^{\prime}=z+(1+\varepsilon)(M-z)$. Plugging in and rearranging for $M^{\prime \prime}$ yields $M^{\prime \prime}=z+(1-\varepsilon)(M-z)$.

$a-t \notin H$, which contradicts that ext $M+t$ and ext $M-t$ are subsets of $A$. Hence the spanning condition $\operatorname{span}\left\{n_{H}\right\}_{H \in \mathcal{F}(M)}=\mathbb{R}^{d}$ is violated. Conversely, if the spanning condition is violated, there is a direction $t \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \backslash\{0\}$ such that $t$ is orthogonal to all the facet normals in $\mathcal{F}(M)$. As in the previous paragraph, ext $M+t$ and ext $M-t$ will still satisfy the facet-defining inequalities of $A$ for $\|t\|$ sufficiently small, i.e. ext $M+t$, ext $M-t \subset A$.

The statement of the of Theorem 5.3 is the contraposition of what we have shown.
D.3. Proofs for Section 6. We use Theorem C. 1 in Appendix C and the notation introduced for this result in the following proof.

Proof of Theorem 6.1. Let $M \in \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{M}$ be the extended menu associated with a mechanism $x \in \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{X}$. Recall that $\operatorname{menu}(x)=\operatorname{ext} M$ by Corollary A. 3 (since $d=2$ ); thus, we show $|\operatorname{ext} M| \leq|\mathcal{F}|$.

If cone $\Theta \neq \mathbb{R}^{2}$, then $V(M) \neq \emptyset$ for otherwise $M \in \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{M}$ has a flexible chain. If cone $\Theta=\mathbb{R}^{2}$ and $V(M)=\emptyset$, then $M$ can only not have a flexible chain if ext $M=B_{1}(M)$. In this case, $|\operatorname{ext} M| \leq|\mathcal{F}|$.Thus, we assume $V(M) \neq \emptyset$ going forward.

Consider any vertex $v \in V(M)$ such that the sequence of subsequent vertices $S=$ $\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{n}\right)$ in the clockwise ordering of ext $M$ satisfies $S \cap V(M)=\emptyset$ and such that $v_{n}$ is adjacent to a vertex $v^{\prime} \in V(M)$. Since $v, v^{\prime} \in \operatorname{ext} A$, let $\left(e_{1}, \ldots, e_{k}\right)$ be the sequence of edges traversed when moving from $v$ to $v^{\prime}$ clockwise on the boundary of $A$. (If $v=v^{\prime}$, then all edges are traversed.)

We show that $n \leq k-1$. Since $M \in \operatorname{ext} M, S$ does not contain a flexible chain. Thus, $\left|\left(B_{2}(M) \cup I(M)\right) \cap S\right|=1$. On every edge $i=2, \ldots k-1$, there lies at most one vertex in ext $M$, for otherwise $\left|B_{2}(M)\right| \geq 2$. Moreover, since $v$ and $v^{\prime}$ lie on $e_{1}$ and $e_{k}$, respectively, there can be at most one vertex in ext $M \backslash\left\{v, v^{\prime}\right\}$ on $e_{1} \cup e_{n}$. (This vertex would have to be in $\left.B_{2}(M)\right)$. Thus, $n \leq k-1$.

By applying the previous argument to every $v \in V(M)$, we conclude that $|\operatorname{ext} M| \leq|\mathcal{F}|$.
Proof of Theorem 6.2. Immediate from Theorem 6.6 below.
Proof of Theorem 6.3. Let $x \in \mathcal{X}$ be exhaustive and such that menu $(x)$ is finite and in general position. Let $M \in \mathcal{M}$ be the associated extended menu. By Corollary A.3, ext $M=\operatorname{menu}(x)$. $M=\operatorname{conv} \operatorname{ext} M+\Theta^{\circ}$ is a polyhedron because ext $M$ is finite and $\Theta^{\circ}$ is a polyhedral cone. Since ext $M$ is in general position, all proper bounded faces of $M$ are simplices. Smilansky (1987, Theorem 5.1) shows that a polyhedron $M$ of which every bounded face is a simplex cannot be represented as a convex combination of polyhedra with the same recession cone as $M$ that are not homothetic to $M$. Therefore, $M$ has no non-homothetic decomposition. By Lemma D.2, $M$ has no homothetic decomposition because $M$ is exhaustive. Thus $M \in \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{M}$, and $x \in \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{X}$ by Theorem A.2.

We may define exhaustiveness for arbitrary subsets $S$ of $A: \mathcal{F}(S) \subseteq \mathcal{F}$ are the facets of $A$ intersected by $S$, and $S$ is exhaustive if there is no $S^{\prime} \subset A$ positively homothetic to $S$ such that $\mathcal{F}(S) \subseteq \mathcal{F}\left(S^{\prime}\right)$. Theorem 5.3 applies as before. Recall that an extended menu $M \in \mathcal{M}$ is exhaustive if ext $M$ is exhaustive.

We use the following simple consequence of Theorem 5.3 in the proof of Theorem 6.4.
Corollary D.3. If $S \subset A$ is exhaustive, then there exists an exhaustive $S^{\prime} \subset S$ such that $\left|\mathcal{F}\left(S^{\prime}\right)\right| \leq d+1$.

Proof. By Theorem 5.3, $\operatorname{span}\left\{n_{H}\right\}_{H \in \mathcal{F}(S)}=\mathbb{R}^{d}$. Thus, there exists a subset $\mathcal{F}^{\prime} \subset \mathcal{F}(S)$ with $\left|\mathcal{F}^{\prime}\right|=d$ such that $\operatorname{span}\left\{n_{H}\right\}_{H \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}}=\mathbb{R}^{d}$. Moreover, by Theorem 5.3, there must exist a hyperplane $H^{\prime} \in \mathcal{F}(S) \backslash \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ such that $\bigcap_{H \in \mathcal{F}(S)} H \cap H^{\prime} \neq \emptyset$. Select $S^{\prime} \subset S$ such that $\mathcal{F}\left(S^{\prime}\right)=\mathcal{F}^{\prime} \cup\left\{F^{\prime}\right\}$. (Clearly, at most $d+1$ points in $S$ suffice.) Theorem 5.3 completes the proof.

Proof of Theorem 6.4. Let $x \in \mathcal{X}$ be exhaustive with associated extended menu $M \in \mathcal{M}$ and such that menu $(x)=\operatorname{ext} M$ is finite. We first construct a menu $\tilde{M} \in \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{M}$ of finite menu size that is arbitrarily close to $M$ in the Hausdorff distance and satisfies $|\operatorname{ext} M|=|\operatorname{ext} \tilde{M}|$. This suffices to show the denseness claim in the statement of Theorem 6.4 by Lemma A.7.

Select an inclusion-wise minimal subset $V \subseteq \operatorname{ext} M$ such that $V$ is exhaustive and $g \in V$. By Corollary D.3, $|V| \leq d+1$. (If $g \in V$, then $|V|=2$ suffices.) If $|V| \leq d$, then $V$ is trivially in general position (i.e., no more than $d$ points lie on any hyperplane in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ ). Suppose $|V|=d+1$. Then every vertex in $V$ touches exactly one of the $d+1$ facets in $\mathcal{F}(V)$ by construction of $V$. Select an arbitrary vertex $v \in V$ and move $v$ to a nearby point $v^{\prime}$ in the same facet of $A$ touched by $v$ that is not in the affine hull of $V \backslash\{v\}$ (which meets the facet of $A$ touched by $v$ in a $(d-2)$-dimensional convex set). Let $W=V \backslash\{v\} \cup\left\{v^{\prime}\right\}$.

Now consider one-by-one $v \in \operatorname{ext} M \backslash V$. Perturb $v$ to a point $v^{\prime} \in A$ arbitrarily close to $v$ such that $v$ does not lie in any hyperplane spanned by any subset of $d$ points in $W$. (This is possible since there are only finitely many such hyperplanes.) Update $W=W \cup\left\{v^{\prime}\right\}$ and $V=V \cup\{v\}$. Proceed iteratively until $V=\operatorname{ext} M$. The resulting set of points $W$ is in general position and exhaustive by construction.

Define $\tilde{M}=\operatorname{conv} W+\Theta^{\circ}$. By construction, $\tilde{M}$ is a polyhedron in $\mathcal{M}$. As long as all of the finitely many perturbations carried out are sufficiently small, $W$ is in convex position, i.e., no point in $W$ is in the convex hull of the other points, because ext $M$ was in convex position. Moreover, for all $v, v^{\prime} \in W, v \notin v^{\prime}+\Theta^{\circ}$ because $\Theta^{\circ}$ is closed and the same holds for all $v, v^{\prime} \in \operatorname{ext} M$. Thus, ext $\tilde{M}=W$ and $\tilde{M}$ is exhaustive because $W$ is exhaustive.
$\tilde{M} \in \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{M}$ by Theorem 6.3 and $|\operatorname{ext} \tilde{M}|=|W|=|\operatorname{ext} M|$ by construction, proving denseness.

For openness, every polytope in a sufficiently small Hausdorff-ball around a simplicial polytope conv ext $M$ is simplicial since the vertices remain in general position (see e.g. Grünbaum et al., 1967, Theorems 5.3.1 and 10.1.1). By Lemmas A. 6 and A.7, the claim follows.

Remark. An alternative statement of Theorem 6.4 is that the set of extreme points of menu size $k$ is relatively open and dense in the set of exhaustive mechanisms of menu size $\leq k$. This is because the set of exhaustive extended menus of menu size $k$ is relatively open and dense in the set of exhaustive extended menus of menu size $\leq k$.

Proof of Corollary 6.5. Take an arbitrary exhaustive extended menu $M \in \mathcal{M}$. Select a finite set of vertices $V \subseteq \operatorname{ext} M$, including $g$ (if $g$ exists) as well as points on the same facets of $A$ as ext $M$, such that for every point of ext $M$ there is a selected point in $V$ at most $\varepsilon>0$ away. By construction, $V$ is an exhaustive set and $g \in V$. Thus, $\tilde{M}=\operatorname{conv} V+\Theta^{\circ} \in \mathcal{M}$ is exhaustive, has finite menu size, and is arbitrarily close to $M$ for $\varepsilon$ sufficiently small. By Theorem 6.4, $\tilde{M}$ is arbitrarily close to an element of ext $M$ with finite menu size, which completes the proof.

The proof of Theorem 6.6 proceeds with Baire-category type arguments, for which we need a few definitions:

- $\operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M} \subset \mathcal{M}$ is the set of exhaustive extended menus;
- $\mathcal{A}_{k} \subset \operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}$ is the set of exhaustive extended menus $M$ such that $M=\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime \prime}$ for $M^{\prime}, M^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{M}$ with $d\left(M^{\prime}, M^{\prime \prime}\right) \geq \frac{1}{k}$;
- $\mathcal{B}_{k} \subset \operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}$ is the set of exhaustive extended menus $M$ that have a bounded face $f$ with $\operatorname{diam}(f) \geq \frac{1}{k}$ and outer unit normal vector $n_{f} \in \Theta$ such that $d\left(n_{f}\right.$, bndr cone $\left.\Theta\right) \geq$ $1 / k$ (which is satisfied by convention if bndr cone $\Theta=\emptyset$, i.e., cone $\left.\Theta=\mathbb{R}^{d}\right) .{ }^{45}$
We note that $\operatorname{ext} \mathcal{M}=\operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M} \backslash \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathcal{A}_{k}$. Moreover, define $\operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}^{s c}:=\operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M} \backslash \bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathcal{B}_{k}$.

Lemma D.4. Let $x \in \mathcal{X}$ be a mechanism associated with an extended menu $M \in \operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}^{s c}$. Then, $x: \Theta \rightarrow A$ is continuous on int cone $\Theta$. In particular, $\operatorname{menu}(x)$ is uncountable whenever it is not a singleton.

Proof. For any $M \in \operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}^{s c}$ and $\theta \in \operatorname{int}$ cone $\Theta, \arg \max _{a \in M} \theta \cdot a$ is a singleton for otherwise the boundary of $M$ would contain a line segment connecting two extreme points of $M$. In particular, $x(\theta)$ is uniquely determined by $M$ on int cone $\Theta$. Therefore, the associated indirect utility function $U$ is differentiable on int cone $\Theta$. By Rockafellar (1997, Corollary 25.5.1), $U$ is continuously differentiable and therefore $x=\nabla U$ is continuous on int cone $\Theta$.

Lemma D.5. $\mathcal{A}_{k}$ and $\mathcal{B}_{k}$ are closed subsets of $\operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}$ for all $k \in \mathbb{N}$.
Proof. Consider any convergent sequence $\left\{M_{i}\right\}_{i \in \mathbb{N}} \subset \mathcal{A}_{k}$ with limit $M \in \operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}$. We show $M \in \mathcal{A}_{k}$. Selecting a subsequence, if necessary, we may assume that the associated sequences $\left\{M_{i}^{\prime}\right\}_{i \in \mathbb{N}} \subset \mathcal{M}$ and $\left\{M_{i}^{\prime \prime}\right\}_{i \in \mathbb{N}} \subset \mathcal{M}$, where $M_{i}=\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime \prime}$, converge in $\mathcal{M}$ by Blaschke's selection theorem and Lemma A.6. Let $M^{\prime}$ and $M^{\prime \prime}$ denote the respective limits. We have $d\left(M^{\prime}, M^{\prime \prime}\right) \geq \frac{1}{k}$ since $d\left(M_{i}^{\prime}, M_{i}^{\prime \prime}\right) \geq \frac{1}{k}$ for all $i \in \mathbb{N}$. Moreover, $M=\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime \prime}$ since $M_{i}=\frac{1}{2} M_{i}^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2} M_{i}^{\prime \prime}$ for all $i \in \mathbb{N}$ and $\mathcal{M}$ is convex, so $\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2} M^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{M}$. Thus, $M \in \mathcal{A}_{k}$.

Consider any convergent sequence $\left\{M_{i}\right\}_{i \in \mathbb{N}} \subset \mathcal{B}_{k}$ with limit $M \in \operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}$. We show $M \in \mathcal{B}_{k}$. By definition, for each $i \in \mathbb{N}$, there exists a line segment $L_{i} \subseteq \operatorname{bndr} M_{i}$ of length $\geq \frac{1}{k}$ with normal vector $n_{i} \in \Theta$ such that $d\left(n_{i}\right.$, bndr cone $\left.\Theta\right) \geq \frac{1}{k}$. Selecting a subsequence, if necessary, we may assume that the line segments $\left\{L_{i}\right\}_{i \in \mathbb{N}}$ and the normal vectors $\left\{n_{i}\right\}_{i \in \mathbb{N}}$ converge to limits $L^{*} \subset A$ and $n^{*} \in \Theta$, respectively, because $\Theta \subseteq \mathbb{S}^{d-1}$ and $A$ are compact. It is routine to verify that $L^{*} \subseteq \operatorname{bndr} M, L^{*}$ has length $\geq \frac{1}{k}, n^{*}$ is normal to $L^{*}$ on bndr $M$, and $d\left(n^{*}\right.$, bndr cone $\left.\Theta\right) \geq \frac{1}{k}$. Thus, $M \in \mathcal{B}_{k}$.

Proof of Theorem 6.6. We show that $\operatorname{ext} \mathcal{M} \cap \operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}^{s c}$ is a dense $G_{\delta}$ in $\operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}$. This implies the statement by Lemma D.4.

The proof uses the Baire category theorem. For this, note that $\operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}$ is a compact metric space, hence a Baire space, because $\operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}$ is a closed subset of the compact metric space $\mathcal{M}$ (Lemmas A. 6 and A.7). The set $\operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}$ is closed because every extended menu in a sufficiently small neighborhood of a non-exhaustive extended menu $M \in \mathcal{M}$ intersects a weakly smaller set of facets of $A$ than $M$ and is hence also non-exhaustive by Theorem 5.3. Thus, it suffices

to show that ext $\mathcal{M}$ and $\operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}^{s c}$ are each a dense $G_{\delta}$ in $\operatorname{exh} \mathcal{M}$. For ext $\mathcal{M}$, this follows immediately from Corollary 6.5 and Lemma D.5.

Proof of Corollary 6.7. Corollary 6.5 shows that the extreme points of $\mathcal{X}$ are dense in the set of exhaustive mechanisms. The Straszewicz-Klee theorem (Klee Jr, 1957, Theorem 2.1) implies that the exposed points of $\mathcal{X}$ are also dense in the set of exhaustive mechanisms. The Riesz representation theorem (Diestel and Uhl, 1977, Theorem IV.1) implies that, for every exposed point $x \in \exp \mathcal{X}$, there exists an objective $v$ and prior $\mu$ such that $x$ is uniquely optimal.

# D.4. Proofs for Section 7. 

Proof of Lemma 7.1. It remains to show that in the linear delegation problem, the indecomposability of an extended menu $M \in \mathcal{M}$ is necessary for the non-existence of a non-homothetic decomposition. We show the converse. Assume that there exists an extended menu $M \in \mathcal{M}$ that is decomposable; that is, there exist convex bodies $K^{\prime}, K^{\prime \prime} \subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$, not homothetic to $M$, such that $M=K^{\prime}+K^{\prime \prime}$.

We aim to construct from these summands $K^{\prime}$ and $K^{\prime \prime}$ a non-homothetic decomposition of $M$ into extended menus. To achieve this, we will identify $\lambda \in(0,1)$ and $t \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ such that the scaled and translated sets $M^{\prime}=\frac{1}{\lambda}\left(K^{\prime}+t\right)$ and $M^{\prime \prime}=\frac{1}{1-\lambda}\left(K^{\prime \prime}-t\right)$ are extended menus, i.e., subsets of the unit simplex $A=\Delta$. This will complete the proof since $M=\lambda M^{\prime}+(1-\lambda) M^{\prime \prime}$.

Since $M \subseteq A=\Delta, M$ satisfies the following constraints:
(1) Positivity: $\min _{a \in M} a_{i} \geq 0$ for all $i \in\{1, \ldots, d\}$;
(2) Size: $\max _{a \in M} \sum_{i=1}^{d} a_{i} \leq 1$.

We will now define $t$ and $\lambda$ such that the above constraints are binding for $M^{\prime}$. This ensures that the constraints are satisfied by $M^{\prime \prime}$ because they are satisfied by $M$ and $M$ is a convex combination of $M^{\prime}$ and $M^{\prime \prime}$. We set

$$
t_{i}=-\min _{a \in K^{\prime}} a_{i}
$$

This ensures $\min _{a \in K^{\prime}+t} a_{i}=0$ for all $i \in\{1, \ldots, d\}$; hence $M^{\prime}$ satisfies the positivity constraint with equality, irrespective of our choice of $\lambda$.

Next, for any convex body $K \subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$, define:

$$
|K|_{\Delta}=\max _{a \in K} \sum_{i=1}^{d} a_{i}-\sum_{i=1}^{d} \min _{a \in K} a_{i}
$$

Note that $|\cdot|_{\Delta}$ commutes with positive scalar multiplication and Minkowski addition; that is, $|\alpha K|_{\Delta}=\alpha|K|_{\Delta}$ and $\left|K_{1}+K_{2}\right|_{\Delta}=\left|K_{1}\right|_{\Delta}+\left|K_{2}\right|_{\Delta}$.

Set

$$
\lambda=\left|K^{\prime}\right|_{\Delta}
$$

Since $K^{\prime}$ and $K^{\prime \prime}$ are not singletons (otherwise, the decomposition would be homothetic), we have $\left|K^{\prime}\right|_{\Delta},\left|K^{\prime \prime}\right|_{\Delta}>0$, hence $\lambda>0$. Since $|M|_{\Delta} \leq 1$, we have $\left|K^{\prime}\right|_{\Delta}<1$ and $\left|K^{\prime \prime}\right|_{\Delta}<1$, hence $\lambda \in(0,1)$.

We can now compute

$$
\max _{a \in M^{\prime}} \sum_{i=1}^{d} a_{i}=\left|M^{\prime}\right|_{\Delta}=\frac{1}{\lambda}\left|K^{\prime}+t\right|_{\Delta}=\frac{1}{\lambda}\left|K^{\prime}\right|_{\Delta}=1
$$

and hence $M^{\prime}$ satisfies the size constraint with equality. Hence, $M^{\prime \prime} \subseteq A$ by the earlier argument, which completes the proof.

# D.5. Proofs for Section 8. 

D.5.1. Undominated Mechanisms. We begin by establishing an important result for the proofs of Theorems 8.5 and 8.7, namely that uniquely optimal mechanisms are dense in the undominated extreme points when considering two mechanisms as being "close" when they are "close" with respect to the induced principal's utility functions. Theorem 8.2 will be proved along the way.

To state the result, let

$$
\mathcal{V}=\{\theta \mapsto x(\theta) \cdot v(\theta) \mid x \in X\}
$$

denote the set of the principal's utility functions induced by the set of (IC) and (IR) mechanisms. This set of functions $\Theta \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is convex and $L^{1}$-compact because it is a continuous image of the compact convex set $\mathcal{X}$.

We say that a principal utility function $V \in \mathcal{V}$ is undominated if there exists an undominated mechanism $x \in \mathcal{X}$ such that $V(\theta)=x(\theta) \cdot v(\theta)$.

We also define the following subsets of $\mathcal{V}$ :

- und $\mathcal{V} \subset \mathcal{V}$ is the set of undominated principal utility functions;
- und $\mathcal{V} \subset$ und $\mathcal{V}$ is the set of undominated principal utility functions that are strictly suboptimal for every probability density $f \in L^{\infty}(\Theta)$ that is uniformly bounded away from 0 ;
- $\exp _{+} \mathcal{V} \subset \mathcal{V}$ is the set of principal utility functions that are uniquely optimal for some probability density $f \in L^{\infty}(\Theta)$ that is uniformly bounded away from 0 . Note $\exp _{+} \mathcal{V} \subset$ und $\mathcal{V} \cap \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{V}$.
As usual, we write $\langle V, f\rangle=\int_{\Theta} V(\theta) f(\theta) d \theta$.
Proposition D.6. $\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}$ is dense in $\operatorname{ext} \mathcal{V} \cap$ und $\mathcal{V}$.
We proof the result in three steps. The argument for the first Lemma is inspired by the argument for Theorem 9 in Manelli and Vincent (2007); note the correction in Manelli and Vincent (2012).

Lemma D.7. und $\mathcal{V} \subseteq \operatorname{clconv}\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right)$.
Proof. Fix any $V \in$ und $\mathcal{V}$. We show the claim by constructing a convergent sequence of points in $\mathcal{V}$ that are convex combinations of points in $\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}$ with limit $V$.

For $\varepsilon \geq 0$, let

$$
F_{\varepsilon}=\left\{f \in L^{\infty}(\Theta) \mid \varepsilon \leq f \leq 1\right\}
$$

Up to renormalization, these functions are essentially bounded probability densities that are uniformly bounded away from zero. By the Banach-Alaoglu theorem, $F_{\varepsilon}$ is weak*-compact because it is a weak*-closed subset of the dual unit ball. ${ }^{46}$

Recall that $V \in \underline{\underline{\operatorname{und}}} \mathcal{V}$, i.e., $V$ is strictly suboptimal for every density $f \in L^{\infty}(\Theta)$ that is uniformly bounded away from 0 . Thus, for every $f \in F_{\varepsilon}$, there exists $V_{f} \in \mathcal{V}$ such that

$$
\left\langle V_{f}, f\right\rangle>\langle V, f\rangle
$$

By the continuity of the evaluation (see e.g. Aliprantis and Border, 2007, Corollary 6.40), for every $f \in F_{\varepsilon}$, there exists a weak*-open neighborhood $O_{f}$ of $f$ such that for all $f^{\prime} \in O_{f}$,

$$
\left\langle V_{f}, f^{\prime}\right\rangle>\left\langle V, f^{\prime}\right\rangle
$$

Thus, $\left\{O_{f}: f \in F_{\varepsilon}\right\}$ is a weak*-open cover of $F_{\varepsilon}$.
By compactness, the open cover $\left\{O_{f}: f \in F_{\varepsilon}\right\}$ has a finite subcover $\left\{O_{m}: m=1, \ldots, M\right\}$. The functionals $f \in F_{\varepsilon}$ that expose a point in $\mathcal{V}$ are norm-dense in $F_{\varepsilon}$ (see e.g. Lau (1976) and note that $F_{\varepsilon}$ has non-empty interior). Thus, for every $m=1, \ldots, M$, there exists $f^{\prime} \in O_{m}$ such that $V_{m}:=V_{f^{\prime}} \in \exp \mathcal{V}$.

Let

$$
G=\left\{\left(\left\langle V_{1}-V, f\right\rangle, \ldots,\left\langle V_{m}-V, f\right\rangle\right) \mid f \in F_{\varepsilon}\right\} \subset \mathbb{R}^{M}
$$

The set $G$ is

- convex (because $F_{\varepsilon}$ is convex);
- compact (because it is the continuous image of a weak*-compact set);
- and satisfies $G \cap \mathbb{R}_{-}^{M}=\emptyset$ (by construction of the open cover $\left\{O_{m}: m=1, \ldots, M\right\}$ ), where $\mathbb{R}_{-}^{M}$ is the negative orthant.
By the Separating Hyperplane Theorem, there exists a vector $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{M} \backslash\{0\}$, such that $\alpha \cdot y>0$ for all $y \in G$. Renormalize $\sum_{i=1}^{M} \alpha_{i}=1$.

Define

$$
\tilde{V}_{\varepsilon}=\sum_{i=1}^{M} \alpha_{i} V_{i}
$$

Note $\tilde{V}_{\varepsilon} \in \mathcal{V}$ since $\mathcal{V}$ is convex. For all $f \in F_{\varepsilon}$,

$$
\left\langle\tilde{V}_{\varepsilon}, f\right\rangle-\langle V, f\rangle=\alpha \cdot\left(\left\langle V_{1}-V, f\right\rangle, \ldots,\left\langle V_{m}-V, f\right\rangle\right)>0
$$

Now consider a sequence $\varepsilon_{n} \rightarrow 0$ and the corresponding sequence of $\tilde{V}_{\varepsilon_{n}}$ constructed above. Since $\mathcal{V}$ is norm-compact, a subsequence of $\left(\tilde{V}_{\varepsilon_{n}}\right)$ converges to some $\tilde{V} \in \mathcal{V}$.

We show $\tilde{V}=V$, which proves the claim. Recall that $V$ is undominated and suppose $\tilde{V} \neq V$. Then there exists a set $\tilde{\Theta} \subset \Theta$ of non-zero (spherical) measure such that $V(\theta)>\tilde{V}(\theta)$ for all $\theta \in \tilde{\Theta}$. Thus, any density $f$ concentrated on $\tilde{\Theta}$ is such that

$$
\langle V, f\rangle>\langle\tilde{V}, f\rangle
$$

By norm-norm continuity of the evaluation, there exists a strictly positive density $f^{\prime}$ and some $\tilde{V}_{\varepsilon_{n}}$ for $n$ large enough such that

$$
\langle V, f\rangle>\left\langle\tilde{V}_{\varepsilon_{n}}, f^{\prime}\right\rangle
$$

a contradiction.

Proof of Theorem 8.2. Follows from the proof for Lemma D. 7 with $\varepsilon=0$.
We now extend Lemma D. 7 to cover all undominated mechanisms.
Lemma D.8. und $\mathcal{V} \subseteq \operatorname{clconv}\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right)$.
Proof. Suppose not, i.e., $V \in$ und $\mathcal{V} \backslash \operatorname{clconv}\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right)$. By Lemma D.7, $V \notin$ und $\mathcal{V}$, i.e., $V$ is optimal for some density $f^{*} \in L^{\infty}(\Theta)$ that is uniformly bounded away from 0 .

Since $\operatorname{clconv}\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right)$ is a closed subset of the norm-compact set $\mathcal{V}$, it is norm-compact. By the Hahn-Banach Separation Theorem, there exists $f \in L^{\infty}(\Theta)$ such that

$$
\langle V, f\rangle>_{\max _{V^{\prime} \in \operatorname{clconv}\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right.}}\left\langle V^{\prime}, f\right\rangle
$$

$\tilde{f}=\varepsilon f+(1-\varepsilon) f^{*}$ is still uniformly bounded away from 0 for $\varepsilon \in(0,1)$ small enough and, moreover, for $\varepsilon \in(0,1)$ small enough

$$
\langle V, \tilde{f}\rangle>_{\max _{V^{\prime} \in \operatorname{clconv}\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right.}}\left\langle V^{\prime}, \tilde{f}\right\rangle
$$

by norm-norm continuity of the evaluation and Berge's maximum theorem (for the RHS). By the result of Lau (1976) used in Lemma D.7, there is another density $\hat{f}$ arbitrarily close to $\tilde{f}$ and therefore also uniformly bounded away from $\varepsilon$ that exposes a point $\hat{V} \in \mathcal{V}$. Again by continuity and Berge's maximum theorem,

$$
\langle V, \hat{f}\rangle>_{\max _{V^{\prime} \in \operatorname{clconv}\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right.}}\left\langle V^{\prime}, \hat{f}\right\rangle
$$

By definition, $\langle\hat{V}, \hat{f}\rangle>\langle V, \hat{f}\rangle$. Thus, the point $\hat{V}$ exposed by $\hat{f}$ cannot be in $\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}$, a contradiction.

We complete the proof of Proposition D.6.
Proof of Proposition D.6. The claim is a consequence of Milman's theorem (see e.g. Klee Jr, 1957, Theorem 1.1.). The theorem implies that $\operatorname{ext} \operatorname{clconv}\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{cl} \exp _{+} \mathcal{V}$ since $\operatorname{clconv}\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right)$ is compact and convex. In particular, by Lemma D.8, every undominated extreme point of $\mathcal{V}$ must be in $\operatorname{clconv}\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right)$. But since $\operatorname{clconv}\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right)$ is a convex subset of $\mathcal{V}$, every undominated extreme point of $\mathcal{V}$ must also be in ext cl conv $\left(\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}\right)$ and therefore arbitrarily close to a point in $\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}$.
D.5.2. Multi-Good Monopoly. We proceed with the multi-good monopoly problem. To follow the standard terminology in mechanism design with transfers, we abuse language and refer to elements of $[0,1]^{m}$ as types and allocations, and consider mechanisms and indirect utility functions as functions defined on $[0,1]^{m}$. In line with standard notation, we also write $(x, t) \in \mathcal{X}$ to separate the "allocation component" of a mechanism from the "transfer component."

We use the following lemma about undominated mechanisms in the upcoming arguments.
Lemma D. 9 (Manelli and Vincent, 2007, Lemma 11). Suppose $\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{X}$ and $(x, t) \in \mathcal{X}$ with indirect utility functions $U^{\prime}$ and $U$, respectively, are such that $t^{\prime} \geq t$ almost everywhere. Then, for all $\theta \in[0,1]^{m}$ and $\lambda \theta \in[0,1]^{m}$ with $\lambda>1$,
(1) $U^{\prime}(\theta)>U(\theta) \Longrightarrow U^{\prime}(\lambda \theta)>U(\lambda \theta)$;
(2) $U^{\prime}(\theta) \geq U(\theta) \Longrightarrow U^{\prime}(\lambda \theta) \geq U(\lambda \theta)$.

Proof of Lemma 8.3. Is is without loss of generality to consider only pricing functions with marginal prices in $[0,1]$ because types are in $[0,1]^{m}$.

Now consider a pricing function $p$ with marginal prices in $[\delta, 1-\delta]$ for some $\delta>0$. Let $(x, t) \in \mathcal{X}$ be the mechanism obtained from $p$, and let $U$ be the associated indirect utility function. For the sake of contradiction, suppose $\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{X}$ dominates $(x, t)$, and let $U^{\prime}$ be the associated indirect utility function.

Since marginal prices are in $[\delta, 1-\delta]$, we have $U^{\prime}(\theta) \geq U(\theta)=0$ for all $\theta \leq(\delta, \ldots, \delta)$. By Lemma D.9, we have $U^{\prime} \geq U$. Thus, there is a type $\theta \in[0,1]^{m}$ such that $U^{\prime}(\theta)>U(\theta)$ (otherwise $x$ and $x^{\prime}$ are payoff-equivalent). By the continuity of indirect utility functions, we may assume $\theta \in(0,1)^{m}$.

Let $\lambda^{1}>1$ be the largest scalar such that $\theta^{1}=\lambda^{1} \theta \in\left[0,1-\frac{\delta}{2}\right]^{m}$, and let $i=1, \ldots, m$ be such that $\theta_{i}^{1}=1-\frac{\delta}{2}$. Without loss of generality, suppose $i=1$. By Lemma D.9, we have $U^{\prime}\left(\theta^{1}\right)>U\left(\theta^{1}\right)$.

Consider the subspace $H^{1}=\left\{\theta \in[0,1]^{m} \mid \theta_{1}=1-\frac{\delta}{2}\right\}$. Up to an arbitrarily small translation of $H^{1}$ in coordinate direction $\pm e_{1}$, we may assume by Fubini's Theorem that $x^{\prime}(\theta) \cdot \theta \geq x(\theta) \cdot \theta$ for almost every $\theta \in H^{1}$ (with respect to $m-1$-dimensional Lebesgue measure) because $U^{\prime} \geq U$ and $t^{\prime} \geq t$ almost everywhere. For all $\theta \in H^{1}$, we have $x_{i}(\theta)=1$ since $\theta_{i}>1-\delta$ and marginal prices are in $[\delta, 1-\delta]$. Together with dominance, we have $x^{\prime}(\theta) \cdot\left(0, \theta_{-1}\right) \geq x(\theta) \cdot\left(0, \theta_{-1}\right)$ for almost every $\theta \in H^{1}$.

Now let $\lambda^{2}>1$ be the largest scalar such that $\theta^{2}=\left(\theta_{1}^{1}, \lambda^{2} \theta_{-1}^{1}\right) \in\left[0,1-\frac{\delta}{2}\right]^{m}$, and let $i=2, \ldots, m$ be such that $\theta_{i}^{2}=1-\frac{\delta}{2}$. Without loss of generality, suppose $i=2$. By the same arguments as for the proof of Lemma D.9, we have $U^{\prime}\left(\theta^{2}\right)>U\left(\theta^{2}\right)$.

Iteratively proceed with this argument, constructing a sequence of affine subspaces $\left(H^{1}, \ldots, H^{m}\right)$ and types $\left(\theta^{1}, \ldots, \theta^{m}\right)$, where $\theta_{k}^{i}=1-\frac{\delta}{2}$ for all $i=1, \ldots, m$ and $k \leq i$, such that $U^{\prime}\left(\theta^{i}\right)>U\left(\theta^{i}\right)$ for all $i=1, \ldots, m$ and $x_{k}^{i}=1$ for all $i=1, \ldots, m$ and $k \leq i$.

Finally, $U^{\prime}\left(\theta^{m}\right)>U(\theta)^{m}$ implies $U^{\prime}(\theta)=x^{\prime}(\theta) \cdot \theta-t^{\prime}(\theta)>x(\theta) \cdot \theta-t(\theta)=U(\theta)$ for all $\theta \in B\left(\theta^{m}\right)$ by continuity, where $B\left(\theta^{m}\right)$ is a sufficiently small ball around $\theta^{m}$. We also have $x(\theta)=(1, \ldots, 1)$ for all $\theta>(1-\delta, \ldots, 1-\delta)$ since marginal prices are in $[\delta, 1-\delta]$. Thus, $t^{\prime}(\theta)<t(\theta)$ for all $\theta \in B\left(\theta^{m}\right)$, a contradiction with dominance.

Proof of Corollary 8.4. Take any pricing function $p$ with marginal prices in $[0,1]$. Then, for $\varepsilon>\delta>0$ small enough, the pricing function $p^{\prime}(a)=(1-\varepsilon) p(a)+\delta a$ has marginal prices uniformly bounded away from 0 and 1 . Moreover, the epigraphs epi $p$ and epi $p^{\prime}$ of $p$ and $p^{\prime}$, respectively, are arbitrarily close in the Hausdorff distance. Thus, the extended menus $M=\operatorname{epi} p+\Theta^{\circ}$ and $M^{\prime}=\operatorname{epi} p^{\prime}+\Theta^{\circ}$ are arbitrarily close in the Hausdorff distance (Lemma A.6). By Lemma A.7, the associated mechanisms $x$ and $x^{\prime}$, respectively, are arbitrarily close in $L^{1}$. By Lemma 8.3, $x^{\prime}$ is undominated.

Proof of Theorem 8.5. The argument for why the undominated extreme points are dense in the set of (IC) and (IR) mechanisms when $m \geq 2$ is analogous to the arguments in the proofs for Section 6 in Appendix D.3. By Corollary 8.4, for every $(x, t) \in \mathcal{X}$, find $\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{X}$ arbitrarily close to $(x, t)$ with marginal prices bounded away from 0 and 1 . Then follow the construction for Corollary 6.5 and then the construction for Theorem 6.4. As long as all perturbations are small enough, the constructed extreme point still has marginal prices bounded away from 0 and 1 and is hence undominated.

We complete the the proof by showing that the mechanisms that are uniquely optimal for some type distribution are dense in the undominated mechanisms.

We first show that if $(x, t),\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{X}$ are undominated and $t=t^{\prime}$ almost everywhere, then $x=x^{\prime}$ almost everywhere. It is easy to show (e.g., using Euler's homogenous function theorem) that $x-x^{\prime}$ is constant on almost every ray from the origin, i.e., HD0 up to tiebreaking. It therefore suffices to show that for every undominated mechanism $(x, t) \in \mathcal{X}$, $\lim _{\theta \rightarrow 0} x(\theta)=0$ (independently of the choice of sequence). Let $p$ denote the pricing function associated with $x$ and assume, for the sake of contradiction, that $\lim _{\theta \rightarrow 0} x(\theta)=a^{*} \neq 0$. Then, $p(a)=0$ for all $a \leq a^{*}$. Define a mechanism $\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{X}$ by letting the agent buy from another pricing schedule

$$
p^{\prime}(a)= \begin{cases}p\left(a+a^{*}\right) & \text { if } a+a^{*} \in[0,1]^{m} \\ \max _{a \in \operatorname{menu}(x)} p(a)+\varepsilon & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

where $\varepsilon>0$. By construction, $p^{\prime}(0)=0$; thus, $\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$ is IC and IR. Since $p^{\prime}$ is obtained from $p$ by translation of the graph of $p$ in direction $-a^{*}$ with a new price $\max _{a \in[0,1]^{m}} p(a)+\varepsilon$ for the grand bundle $a=1$, almost every type either buys the same allocation as under $p$ translated by $-a^{*}$ or the grand bundle. Thus, $t^{\prime} \geq t$ almost everywhere. For all sufficiently small $\varepsilon>0$, a positive measure of types will buy the grand bundle. Thus, $\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)$ dominates $(x, t)$, a contradiction.

We next claim that ext $\mathcal{V} \cap$ und $\mathcal{V}$ is dense in und $\mathcal{V}$, where $\mathcal{V}$ is the set of IC transfer functions. If $(x, t) \in \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{X}$ is undominated, then $t \in \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{V}$. To see this, suppose $t=\frac{1}{2} t^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2} t^{\prime \prime} \notin \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{V}$ for $t^{\prime}, t^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{V}$. Define $\tilde{x}=\frac{1}{2} x^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2} x^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{X}$, where $x^{\prime}, x^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{X}$ induce transfer $t^{\prime}$ and $t^{\prime \prime}$, respectively. By definition, $x$ and $\tilde{x}$ both induce $t$. Thus, $x=\tilde{x}$ by the previous paragraph, so $x \notin \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{X}$. The claim now follows because the undominated mechanisms in ext $\mathcal{X}$ are dense in the undominated mechanisms in $\mathcal{X}$.

Fix any undominated mechanism $(x, t) \in \mathcal{X}$. By Proposition D. 6 and the previous paragraph, there exists a sequence of transfer functions $\left(t_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \subset \exp _{+} \mathcal{V}$, each uniquely optimal for some type distribution $\mu$, converging to $t$ in $L^{1}$. We have shown above that the associated sequence of allocation rules $\left(x_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ is uniquely determined. Since $\mathcal{X}$ is compact, up to taking a subsequence, $\left(x_{n}, t_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ converges in $L^{1}$ to some $\left(x^{\prime}, t\right) \in \mathcal{X}$. But $(x, t)$ is undominated, hence $x=x^{\prime}$, as desired.

# D.5.3. Linear Veto Bargaining. We proceed with the linear veto bargaining problem. 

Proof of Lemma 8.6. We first show that the conditions given in the statement are necessary. For this, fix any mechanism $x \in \mathcal{X}$. It is clear that $a \in \operatorname{menu}(x)$ for otherwise $x$ does not satisfy (IR) since there is a type $\theta$ for which $a$ is their (unique) most preferred alternative in $A$. Next suppose menu $(x)$ does not contain the principal's (unique) favorite alternative $a^{*} \in \operatorname{ext} A$. Obtain a new mechanism $x^{\prime} \in X$ by letting the agent choose from $\operatorname{menu}(x) \cup\left\{a^{*}\right\}$. Thus, for all $\theta \in \Theta$, either $x^{\prime}(\theta)=x(\theta)$ or $x^{\prime}(\theta)=a^{*}$. Since $a^{*} \in \operatorname{ext} A$, there is a positive measure of types for which $a^{*}$ is their most preferred allocation in $A$. Thus, $x^{\prime}$ dominates $x$.

For sufficiency, let $a^{*} \in \operatorname{ext} A$ be the principal's favorite alternative and suppose $x, x^{\prime} \in \mathcal{X}$ are such that $a^{*} \in \operatorname{menu}(x), \operatorname{menu}\left(x^{\prime}\right)$ and $x(\theta) \cdot \bar{v} \geq x^{\prime}(\theta) \cdot \bar{v}$ for almost all $\theta \in \Theta$. We show that $x=x^{\prime}$ almost everywhere. We extend both mechanisms to cone $\Theta=\mathbb{R}^{d}$ by letting each type chose their favorite allocation in $\operatorname{menu}(x)$ and $\operatorname{menu}\left(x^{\prime}\right)\left(x\right.$ and $x^{\prime}$ are constant along

almost every ray from the origin). Let $U$ and $U^{\prime}$ be the agent's indirect utility functions associated with $x$ and $x^{\prime}$, respectively.

We claim that for all $\theta \in \operatorname{cone} \Theta$ and $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
\phi_{\theta}(\lambda):=U(\theta+\lambda \bar{v})=U(\theta)+\int_{0}^{\lambda}\langle x(\theta+z \bar{v}), \bar{v}\rangle d z
$$

and analogously for $\phi_{\theta}^{\prime}, x^{\prime}$, and $U^{\prime}$. Recall that $x(\theta)=\partial U(\theta)$ and $x^{\prime}(\theta)=\partial U^{\prime}(\theta)$ (Theorem A.2). $\phi_{\theta}(\lambda)$ is the restriction of a continuous convex function to a line, hence continuous and convex. It is easy to verify that $\langle x(\theta+\lambda \bar{v}), \bar{v}\rangle$ as a function of $\lambda$ is a subgradient of $\phi_{\theta}(\lambda)$. Hence the envelope formula follows (Rockafellar, 1997, Theorem 24.2).

By Fubini's theorem, $\phi_{\theta}(\lambda)-\phi_{\theta}^{\prime}(\lambda)$ is non-decreasing for almost all $\theta \in \operatorname{cone} \Theta$ because $x(\theta+\lambda \bar{v}) \cdot \bar{v} \geq x^{\prime}(\theta+\lambda \bar{v}) \cdot \bar{v}$ for almost all $\theta \in \operatorname{cone} \Theta$ and all $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}$.

For all sufficiently large $\lambda>0$, we have $x(\theta+\lambda \bar{v})=x^{\prime}(\theta+\lambda \bar{v})=a^{*}$ since $a^{*} \in \operatorname{ext} A$ is the principal's, i.e., type $\bar{v}$ 's, (unique) favorite alternative in $A$ and thus the favorite alternative of type $\theta+\lambda \bar{v}$. Thus, $\phi_{\theta}(\lambda)-\phi_{\theta}^{\prime}(\lambda)=0$ for all sufficiently large $\lambda>0$.

Similarly, for all sufficiently small $\lambda<0$, we have $x(\theta+\lambda \bar{v})=x^{\prime}(\theta+\lambda \bar{v})=a$ since $a$ is, by assumption, the principal's (unique) least preferred alternative and the principal's and agent's preferences are sufficiently aligned.

Thus, for almost every $\theta \in \operatorname{cone} \Theta$ and every $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}$, we have $\phi_{\theta}(\lambda)=\phi_{\theta}^{\prime}(\lambda)$ since $\phi_{\theta}(\lambda)-\phi_{\theta}^{\prime}(\lambda)$ is non-decreasing. Put differently, $U=U^{\prime}$ almost everywhere. By continuity, $U=U^{\prime}$. Consequently, $x=x^{\prime}$ almost everywhere.

Proof of Theorem 8.7. The argument for statement (1) is immediate from Theorem 7.2 and Lemma 8.6. We proceed with statement (2).

The argument for why the undominated extreme points are dense in the undominated mechanisms when $m \geq 4$ is completely analogous to the proofs of Corollary 6.5 and Theorem 6.4 when making sure that $a, a^{*} \in V$, where $a^{*}$ is the principal's favorite alternative and $V$ is the set of vertices constructed in the proof of Theorem 6.4.

We complete the the proof by showing that the mechanisms that are uniquely optimal for some type distribution are dense in the undominated mechanisms.

The proof of Lemma 8.6 shows that if $x, x^{\prime} \in \mathcal{X}$ are undominated and such that $x(\theta) \cdot \bar{v}=$ $x(\theta) \cdot \bar{v}$ for almost every $\theta \in \Theta$, then $x=x^{\prime}$ almost everywhere. Thus, an undominated principal utility function uniquely determines an undominated mechanism.

We claim that ext $\mathcal{V} \cap$ und $\mathcal{V}$ is dense in und $\mathcal{V}$. If $x \in \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{X}$ is undominated, then the induced principal utility function $V \in \mathcal{V}$ is in ext $\mathcal{V}$. To see this, suppose $V=\frac{1}{2} V^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2} V^{\prime \prime} \notin \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{V}$ for $V^{\prime}, V^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{V}$. Define $\tilde{x}=\frac{1}{2} x^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2} x^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{X}$, where $x^{\prime}, x^{\prime \prime} \in \mathcal{X}$ induce $V^{\prime}$ and $V^{\prime \prime}$, respectively. By definition, $x$ and $\tilde{x}$ both induce $v$. Thus, $x=\tilde{x}$ by the previous paragraph, so $x \notin \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{X}$. The claim now follows because the undominated mechanisms in ext $\mathcal{X}$ are dense in the undominated mechanisms in $\mathcal{X}$.

Fix any undominated mechanism $x \in \mathcal{X}$. Let $V \in \mathcal{V}$ be the associated principal utility function. By Proposition D. 6 and the previous paragraph, there is a sequence $\left(V_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \subset$ $\exp _{+} \mathcal{V}$ of uniquely optimal undominated principal utility functions converging to $V$. Let $\left(x_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \subset \operatorname{ext} \mathcal{X}$ be the sequence of mechanisms that is uniquely determined by $\left(V_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$. (By definition, each mechanism in the sequence is uniquely optimal for some type distribution.) By compactness of $\mathcal{X}$, up to taking a subsequence, $x_{n} \rightarrow x^{\prime} \in \mathcal{X}$. By continuity of the map that assigns to each mechanism in $\mathcal{X}$ a principal utility function in $\mathcal{V}, x^{\prime}$ must induce $V$ since

$V_{n} \rightarrow V$. Therefore, $x^{\prime}$ is undominated. Thus, $x=x^{\prime}$ almost everywhere, which completes the proof.

abstract:
This paper characterizes extreme points of the set of incentive-compatible
mechanisms for screening problems with linear utility. Extreme points are
exhaustive mechanisms, meaning their menus cannot be scaled and translated to
make additional feasibility constraints binding. In problems with
one-dimensional types, extreme points admit a tractable description with a
tight upper bound on their menu size. In problems with multi-dimensional types,
every exhaustive mechanism can be transformed into an extreme point by applying
an arbitrarily small perturbation. For mechanisms with a finite menu, this
perturbation displaces the menu items into general position. Generic exhaustive
mechanisms are extreme points with an uncountable menu. Similar results hold in
applications to delegation, veto bargaining, and monopoly problems, where we
consider mechanisms that are unique maximizers for specific classes of
objective functionals. The proofs involve a novel connection between menus of
extreme points and indecomposable convex bodies, first studied by Gale (1954).
